articles.headline: Dropbox Shares Leap in I.P.O., and Silicon Valley Smiles
articles.snippet: Shares of the file-sharing company jumped 36 percent on their first day of trading Friday. The debut is a promising sign for other start-ups.
articles.abstract: Shares of the file-sharing company jumped 36 percent on their first day of trading Friday. The debut is a promising sign for other start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dropbox, the file-sharing company and Silicon Valley darling, had a strong market debut Friday, a reassuring sign for the technology industry and for the investors who have billions locked up in other highly valued but privately held start-ups.

articles.headline: After Another Week of Chaos, Trump Repairs to Palm Beach. No One Knows What Comes Next.
articles.snippet: President Trump’s head-spinning moves on national security, the budget and trade left Washington reeling and a bewildered sense of resignation in the West Wing.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s head-spinning moves on national security, the budget and trade left Washington reeling and a bewildered sense of resignation in the West Wing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump decamped to his oceanfront estate here on Friday after a head-spinning series of presidential decisions on national security, trade and the budget that left the capital reeling and his advisers nervous about what comes next.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: At Hamburger Central, Antibiotics for Cattle That Aren’t Sick
articles.snippet: Many industrial feedlots see routine use of antibiotics as essential. Some cattlemen disagree, calling them “performance enhancing drugs.”
articles.abstract: Many industrial feedlots see routine use of antibiotics as essential. Some cattlemen disagree, calling them “performance enhancing drugs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Holland holds a Mason jar, tilting it slightly to show the powdery 90 milligrams of the antibiotic tylosin inside.

articles.headline: For the U.S. and China, a Technology Cold War That’s Freezing Over
articles.snippet: In advanced industries like chip development, the rivals are vying for dominance in a fight that is as much about national security as economic might.
articles.abstract: In advanced industries like chip development, the rivals are vying for dominance in a fight that is as much about national security as economic might.
articles.lead_paragraph: A cold war is being waged across the world’s most advanced industries. And it just got a lot chillier.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Uber’s Self-Driving Cars Were Struggling Before Arizona Crash
articles.snippet: Company documents obtained by The New York Times show Uber was becoming more aggressive with its autonomous car research, even as the technology faltered.
articles.abstract: Company documents obtained by The New York Times show Uber was becoming more aggressive with its autonomous car research, even as the technology faltered.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s robotic vehicle project was not living up to expectations months before a self-driving car operated by the company struck and killed a woman in Tempe, Ariz.

articles.headline: The Former Khmer Rouge Slave Who Blew the Whistle on Wells Fargo
articles.snippet: Duke Tran was a prisoner in Cambodia. He escaped to America and got a job at Wells Fargo. Then he encountered what he alleged was wrongdoing and had to decide what to do.
articles.abstract: Duke Tran was a prisoner in Cambodia. He escaped to America and got a job at Wells Fargo. Then he encountered what he alleged was wrongdoing and had to decide what to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Duke Tran escaped from slavery, but before he became a millionaire, he was a Wells Fargo employee.

articles.headline: In Sweden’s Preschools, Boys Learn to Dance and Girls Learn to Yell
articles.snippet: The state curriculum urges teachers to “counteract traditional gender roles,” and at one school, girls are encouraged to shout “No!” and boys run the play kitchen.
articles.abstract: The state curriculum urges teachers to “counteract traditional gender roles,” and at one school, girls are encouraged to shout “No!” and boys run the play kitchen.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Something was wrong with the Penguins, the incoming class of toddlers at the Seafarer’s Preschool, in a wooded suburb south of Stockholm.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tariffs Keep Allies, Markets and Industry Guessing
articles.snippet: A chaotic rollout of steel and aluminum tariffs, including a last-minute list of countries temporarily exempted from them, has left trade experts puzzled.
articles.abstract: A chaotic rollout of steel and aluminum tariffs, including a last-minute list of countries temporarily exempted from them, has left trade experts puzzled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s flurry of trade moves this past week raised uncertainty and confusion among financial markets, trading partners, lawmakers and American industry, prompting many to ask what, exactly, his endgame might be.

articles.headline: How Calls for Privacy May Upend Business for Facebook and Google
articles.snippet: Internet companies were built on a model in which people gave up their information for free services. Now, that idea is under siege.
articles.abstract: Internet companies were built on a model in which people gave up their information for free services. Now, that idea is under siege.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The contemporary internet was built on a bargain: Show us who you really are and the digital world will be free to search or share.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld, Natasha Singer and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Students Lead Huge Rallies for Gun Control Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: The young people, as they seized the nation’s attention, vowed that their grief about school shootings and their frustration with adults’ inaction would power a new generation of activism.
articles.abstract: The young people, as they seized the nation’s attention, vowed that their grief about school shootings and their frustration with adults’ inaction would power a new generation of activism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing before vast crowds from Washington to Los Angeles to Parkland, Fla., the speakers — nearly all of them students, some still in elementary school — delivered an anguished and defiant message: They are “done hiding” from gun violence, and will “stop at nothing” to get politicians to finally prevent it.

articles.headline: ‘We Are Ready to Die.’ Five North Korean Defectors Who Never Made It.
articles.snippet: Around 30,000 North Koreans have successfully defected to the South. But under the reign of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, far fewer people are getting out.
articles.abstract: Around 30,000 North Koreans have successfully defected to the South. But under the reign of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, far fewer people are getting out.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Ms. Choi was worried about her sister in North Korea.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Su-Hyun Lee

articles.headline: Gun Marches Keep Republicans on Defense in Midterm Races
articles.snippet: The March for Our Lives is another display of energy on the left, but the gun issue could play out differently in House and Senate races.
articles.abstract: The March for Our Lives is another display of energy on the left, but the gun issue could play out differently in House and Senate races.
articles.lead_paragraph: The passionate gun control rallies Saturday that brought out large crowds around the country sent a vivid signal that the issue is likely to play a major role in the 2018 midterm elections, and that Republicans could find themselves largely on the defensive on gun issues for the first time in decades.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: To Invade Homes, Tech Is Trying to Get in Your Kitchen
articles.snippet: For many people, kitchens are the center of the home. Tech and appliance makers, aiming to deepen ties to customers, are increasingly targeting that room with smart devices.
articles.abstract: For many people, kitchens are the center of the home. Tech and appliance makers, aiming to deepen ties to customers, are increasingly targeting that room with smart devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a recent Saturday night, German Salazar made chicken tacos for his friends while they chatted with him in his kitchen. Occasionally, he interrupted the conversation to talk to another friend: Google.

articles.headline: As Amazon Steps Up Tax Collections, Some Cities Are Left Out
articles.snippet: Amazon now collects sales tax in every state that has one, but a report finds that the company still doesn’t collect local taxes in dozens of cities.
articles.abstract: Amazon now collects sales tax in every state that has one, but a report finds that the company still doesn’t collect local taxes in dozens of cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Amazon agreed last year to begin collecting sales tax in New Mexico, state officials celebrated what they said could be tens of millions of dollars in annual tax revenue.

articles.headline: Apple Goes to Hollywood. Will Its Story Have a Happy Ending?
articles.snippet: The company is making deals with Steven Spielberg and other big names. But can it avoid the fate of other tech giants who entered the entertainment business?
articles.abstract: The company is making deals with Steven Spielberg and other big names. But can it avoid the fate of other tech giants who entered the entertainment business?
articles.lead_paragraph: Known for its bold designs and its big marketing campaigns, Apple relishes its status as a dominant force in the corporate world. So it was noteworthy when one of its executives, Eddy Cue, struck a note of humility during a discussion this month at the South by Southwest conference in Austin, Tex.

articles.headline: Stormy Daniels Tells ‘60 Minutes’ That Fear of Trump Kept Her Silent
articles.snippet: The pornographic film actress, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, told “60 Minutes” that a man had threatened her after she sold her claims of an affair with Donald Trump to a magazine in 2011.
articles.abstract: The pornographic film actress, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, told “60 Minutes” that a man had threatened her after she sold her claims of an affair with Donald Trump to a magazine in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pornographic film star Stephanie Clifford told “60 Minutes” that she struck a $130,000 deal for her silence about an alleged affair with Donald J. Trump in the final days of the 2016 campaign because she was worried about her safety and that of her young daughter.

articles.headline: At a Crucial Juncture, Trump’s Legal Defense Is Largely a One-Man Operation
articles.snippet: President Trump is struggling to find any top lawyers willing to represent him as he faces a critical decision: whether to give the special counsel an interview.
articles.abstract: President Trump is struggling to find any top lawyers willing to represent him as he faces a critical decision: whether to give the special counsel an interview.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Trump heads into one of the most critical phases of the special counsel’s investigation, his personal legal team has shrunk to essentially just one member, and he is struggling to find any top lawyers willing to represent him.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: When Professionals Rise Up, More Than Money Is at Stake
articles.snippet: The teacher uprising that began in West Virginia has exposed a trend among white-collar workers: a feeling that their credentials are being devalued.
articles.abstract: The teacher uprising that began in West Virginia has exposed a trend among white-collar workers: a feeling that their credentials are being devalued.
articles.lead_paragraph: When 20,000 West Virginia teachers staged a rare statewide walkout, questions of pay and benefits dominated the headlines. But those concerns could not fully account for the teachers’ ferocious resolve. After all, stagnant wages and receding benefits have been an issue for workers for decades.

articles.headline: Fund-Raiser Held Out Access to Trump as a Prize for Prospective Clients
articles.snippet: The fund-raiser, Elliott Broidy, suggested to prospective clients of his security firm, including some with unsavory records, that he could arrange meetings with the president or his associates.
articles.abstract: The fund-raiser, Elliott Broidy, suggested to prospective clients of his security firm, including some with unsavory records, that he could arrange meetings with the president or his associates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Elliott Broidy, Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign represented an unparalleled political and business opportunity.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Grocery Wars Turn Small Chains Into Battlefield Casualties
articles.snippet: At stake is the fate of thousands of supermarket workers, many of whom belong to labor unions and are owed pensions when they retire.
articles.abstract: At stake is the fate of thousands of supermarket workers, many of whom belong to labor unions and are owed pensions when they retire.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESTERTOWN, N.Y. — At the Tops Market on Main Street recently, there was a “Mega Meat Sale” — buy one pork chop and get another free.
